Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209B (UCCJEA).proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this proceeding pursuant to the Massachusetts Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209B (UCCJEA), and the general jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court over custody and modification matters.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a751A.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, §51A (duty to report child abuse and neglect) (relevant to safety concerns and reporting obligations);

Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: See, e.g., Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209B (UCCJEA) (jurisdiction and enforcement of custody matters); see also Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (recognizing fundamental parental rights and the child’s best-interest inquiry).
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel squarely recognizes that parents have a fundamental liberty interest in the care, custody, and control of their children, and that state interference based solely on a judge’s independent “best interests” view is constitutionally constrained. The plurality discusses the “best interests of the child” standard at length and holds that, as applied, the Washington statute’s pure best‑interest regime impermissibly infringed fundamental parental rights. Thus, it is accurate to cite Troxel for recognizing fundamental parental rights and addressing the best‑interest inquiry, even though it does not concern UCCJEA jurisdiction or enforcement.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The liberty interest at issue in this case—the interest of parents in the care, custody, and control of their children—is perhaps the oldest of the fundamental liberty interests recognized by this Court. … In light of this extensive precedent, it cannot now be doubted that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children. … [T]he Due Process Clause does not permit a State to infringe on the fundamental right of parents to make child rearing decisions simply because a state judge believes a ‘better’ decision could be made.”

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).proposition: - Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982) (parental rights principles);
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition cites Santosky for general "parental rights principles." This opinion squarely addresses the constitutional protection of parental rights, recognizing them as a fundamental liberty interest and holding that due process requires at least clear and convincing evidence before terminating those rights. Thus, it is an appropriate and accurate authority for general principles concerning the constitutional status of parental rights and procedural protections in termination proceedings.
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The fundamental liberty interest of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their child does not evaporate simply because they have not been model parents or have lost temporary custody of their child to the State… When the State moves to destroy weakened familial bonds, it must provide the parents with fundamentally fair procedures.” Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 753–54 (1982).

Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972).proposition: - Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972) (parental liberty interest);
Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes a constitutionally protected liberty interest of a parent—specifically an unwed father—in the care, custody, and management of his children, protected by the Due Process Clause. The Court holds that, because of this parental interest, the state may not remove his children without an individualized hearing on his fitness, thus making the case good authority for the existence of a parental liberty interest. The equal protection discussion builds on this due process-based recognition of a protected parental right.
Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972).relevant_excerpt: “The private interest here, that of a man in the children he has sired and raised, undeniably warrants deference and, absent a powerful countervailing interest, protection. It is plain that the interest of a parent in the companionship, care, custody, and management of his or her children ‘come[s] to this Court with a momentum for respect….’ … These authorities make it clear that, at the least, Stanley’s interest in retaining custody of his children is cognizable and substantial.”

Lassiter v. Dept. of Social Services, 45.raw_text: Lassiter v. Dept. of Social Services, 452 U.S. 18 (1981)
Lassiter v. Dept. of Social Services, 45.proposition: - Lassiter v. Dept. of Social Services, 452 U.S. 18 (1981) (procedural protections in child welfare proceedings);
Lassiter v. Dept. of Social Services, 45.case_name: Lassiter v. Department of Social Servs. of Durham Cty.
Lassiter v. Dept. of Social Services, 45.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses what procedural protections are constitutionally required in child welfare termination-of-parental-rights proceedings, specifically whether due process mandates appointed counsel for indigent parents. Although the Court ultimately holds there is no automatic right to counsel in every termination case, it articulates the governing Mathews v. Eldridge balancing framework and discusses the nature and weight of the parent’s interests, the state’s interests, and the risk of error—i.e., the procedural protections analysis in child welfare proceedings. Thus it is an appropriate authority for the general proposition that Lassiter concerns procedural protections in child welfare proceedings.
Lassiter v. Dept. of Social Services, 45.relevant_excerpt: “The case of Mathews v. Eldridge…propounds three elements to be evaluated in deciding what due process requires, viz., the private interests at stake, the government’s interest, and the risk that the procedures used will lead to erroneous decisions. We must balance these elements…against the presumption that there is a right to appointed counsel only when, if he loses, he may be deprived of his physical liberty.… We therefore adopt the standard found appropriate in Gagnon v. Scarpelli, and leave the decision whether due process calls for the appointment of counsel for indigent parents in termination proceedings to be answered in the first instance by the trial court….”

In re Welfare of Minor Children.raw_text: In re Welfare of Minor Children
In re Welfare of Minor Children.proposition: See, e.g., In re Welfare of Minor Children, and applicable Massachusetts caselaw applying the best-interests standard.
